query: What is the gold medal threshold for the Random Acts of Pizza competition and what scores did winners actually achieve?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: The available Kaggle leaderboard shows that the top competitors each earned a perfect score of 1.00000, but the competition’s gold‑medal threshold is not listed in the current sources. ([kaggle.com](https://www.kaggle.com/c/random-acts-of-pizza/leaderboard))

results.title: The Vera Pizza Contest 2025 awards the title to Pasquale Visone
results.text:
AVPN - The Vera Pizza Contest 2025 awards the title to Pasquale Visone
# [The Vera Pizza Contest 2025 awards the title to Pasquale Visone](339-the_vera_pizza_contest_2025_awards_the_title_to_pasquale_visone)
![The Vera Pizza Contest 2025 awards the title to Pasquale Visone](https://www.pizzanapoletana.org/foto/news/i_vincitori2471765539529.jpg)
965 pizzas from 42 countries took part in the world tournament of homemade pizza.
### The**Best AVPN Pizzeria 2025**kicks off, closing on December 16th: the only contest where pizzaioli are judged by their own colleagues. This will be the most international edition ever, with 62 nations involved.
AVPN closes a record-breaking edition of the Vera Pizza Contest 2025: the 1,360 pizzas submitted from 42 countries, of which 965 were admitted to the competition (the others excluded for not meeting the requirements set by the regulations), once again onfirm the international scope of an initiative that continues to grow in both numbers and quality of participants. After two months of selections, the winner was**Pasquale Visone**, Neapolitan by birth but adopted by Veneto, who, in addition to the great satisfaction of reaching the top step of the podium, received as first prize a 9-day professional course at the AVPN School. Second place went to**Roberto Del Giudice**, awarded a 3-day course with the Association’s pizzaioli; while**Patryk Chorąży**received a 4-hour course.
All finalists also received a series of gifts such as mixers, ovens, various equipment, and a selection of high-quality food products provided by partners Molino Caputo, KYS Norway, Gimetal, Sorì Italia, and Mec Palmieri. The three pizzaioli who competed in front of the AVPN headquarters in Capodimonte were determined by a jury of 14 master pizzaioli, who this year replaced the Facebook audience during the grand finale.
> > “Once again this edition offered an exciting competition, showing how the passion for pizza is increasingly becoming a global phenomenon,” said **> Paolo Surace
**> , AVPN Secretary General. “Selections began on October 22nd and brought us to today’s three finalists. A special thanks to the jury composed of Peter Surace, Luciano Pignataro, and Giusy Ferraina for their professionalism, and to all the pizzaioli who helped confirm the central role of our Association.”
> > > “Winning the contest is an immense emotion,” declared the winner. “This award is a huge incentive to continue growing. I thank AVPN and all the master pizzaioli for their precious work, protecting the tradition of true Neapolitan pizza while opening the doors to those like me who want to learn and challenge themselves.”
> A global competition now gives way to another worldwide contest: the**Best AVPN Pizzeria 2025**, the first and only tournament where pizzaioli themselves act as judges. The seventh edition this year reaches 62 nations with the entry of the first pizzerias in India and the Philippines, and sees over a thousand participants competing, evaluated not only on the quality of the pizza but also on the choice of raw materials, pairings, table service, and location. After the success of past editions that crowned*La Notizia*by Enzo Coccia,*50 Kalò*by Ciro Salvo,*Pizzeria da Attilio*by Attilio Bachetti,*Casa De Rinaldi*by Salvatore De Rinaldi,*Leggera*by Andrè Guidon, and*Zielona Górka*by Jędrzej Lewandowski, Best AVPN Pizzeria is ready to continue celebrating the great talents of pizza across all continents.
> > “We are truly excited to see, year after year, the growing number of pizzerias choosing to join our Association,” said **> Antonio Pace
**> , President of AVPN. “With the entry of the first addresses in India and the Philippines, we open the most international edition ever of Best AVPN Pizzeria: a title of unique value where pizzaioli themselves choose the winner, the most authentic demonstration of the spirit of sharing and growth that animates our community.”
> ### Hall of Fame – Best AVPN Pizzeria
* **Enzo Coccia**: Born in 1962, a true Neapolitan, he is one of Italy’s most influential master pizzaioli. He entered the pizza world at a young age when he took over*Fortuna*, the historic family trattoria in Naples’ old town, and began collaborating with AVPN. In the mid-1990s he opened*La Notizia*on Via Caravaggio, an intimate and modern venue away from tourist flows, which quickly became a reference point for take-away pizza and creative pairings, winning Best AVPN Pizzeria in 2014.
* **Ciro Salvo**: A native of Vesuvius and third generation of a historic pizzaioli family, he opened*50 Kalò*, first in Naples, then in London and Rome. A devotee of Neapolitan tradition, Salvo is known and loved for the lightness and digestibility of his doughs. As a master pizzaiolo, he combines the choice of quality raw materials with experimentation in flavor pairings. His pizzas embody the perfect synthesis of tradition, research, and gourmet combinations, earning him international fame and the Best AVPN Pizzeria award in 2019.
* **Attilio Bachetti**: Born in Naples in 1967, he fell in love with pizza from childhood. Over the years, his passion grew into a true lifestyle, carrying forward the family business opened by his grandfather in 1938 with dedication, passion, and research. His studies also made him a sommelier and expert in cheeses and extra virgin olive oil. Faithful to tradition, he continues to amaze enthusiasts with unmistakable Neapolitan flavors, light and well-leavened dough, while embracing creativity and innovation. Recognized with the Best AVPN Pizzeria award in 2021.
* **Salvatore De Rinaldi**: Born in 1970, he began working at the family business*Ristorante Pizzeria La Stella*at a young age, where he fell in love with the art of pizza. In 1989 he launched the brand*Sasà Pizza Mia*. De Rinaldi invested in training with numerous experiences across Italy to deepen his knowledge of leavening and gourmet toppings. A master of dough, he focuses on natural fermentation and the search for top-quality local ingredients. His*Pizzeria De Rinaldi*is recognized as the home of true Neapolitan pizza, confirmed by the Best AVPN Pizzeria award.
* **Andrè Guidon**: An engineer by training, he loves precision. Unable to digest São Paulo-style pizza, he decided to open his authentic pizzeria*Leggera*to create a product that met his expectations. His success and recognition proved him right. As President of AVPN Brazil, ten years after his first venue he opened a second. Last year was full of triumphs: winning Best AVPN Pizzeria, first place at*50Top Pizza Latin America*, third worldwide, and reconfirmation of the prestigious*Tre Spicchi*award by Gambero Rosso.
* **Jędrzej Lewandowski**: A Polish pizzaiolo known as the founder and face of*Zielona Górka*, a pizzeria in Pabianice that has become an international reference point for Neapolitan pizza. A graduate in architecture, Lewandowski worked for years as a designer before changing paths. Driven by his passion for gastronomy and Neapolitan tradition, he studied the art of pizza seriously, attending specialized courses in Naples and obtaining AVPN certifications.
Friday 12 December 2025
Categories:[Press Area](https://www.pizzanapoletana.org/en/cat/1-press_area),[Approved](https://www.pizzanapoletana.org/en/cat/3-approved),[Vera Pizza Day](https://www.pizzanapoletana.org/en/cat/6-vera_pizza_day),[Vera Pizza Contest](https://www.pizzanapoletana.org/en/cat/2-vera_pizza_contest),[sonoVerace](https://www.pizzanapoletana.org/en/cat/4-sonoverace)

results.title: How to Read an Olive Oil Label
results.text: How to Read an Olive Oil Label | The Olive Oil Professor [![The Olive Oil Professor ](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/06c902f1-f615-4820-84af-78bbceb0f540/oilve+oil+logo.jpg)](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/) [Cart0](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/cart) [](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/search) Back[Italy](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/blog/tag/Italy)[Greece](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/blog/tag/Greece)[California](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/blog/tag/California)[Spain](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/blog/tag/Spain)[Croatia](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/blog/tag/Croatia) Back[cheese professor](https://www.cheeseprofessor.com/)[chocolate professor](https://www.thechocolateprofessor.com/)[alcohol professor](https://www.alcoholprofessor.com/)[vinegar professir](https://www.vinegarprofessor.com/) [Cart0](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/cart) [![The Olive Oil Professor ](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/06c902f1-f615-4820-84af-78bbceb0f540/oilve+oil+logo.jpg)](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/) # How to Read an Olive Oil Label ![Olive oil label with certifications](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/354b9001-aae8-440d-8ad7-6606189c256d/Olive+oil+label+with+certifications.jpeg) The first time I thought deeply about olive oil labels was almost a decade ago, when I worked at Fairway Market. The olive oil section was prodigious, and part of my job was writing signs and material to communicate what set apart our hundreds of extra virgin olive oils. The labels were everything from beautiful to barebones, minimalist to magnificent, and included text in all sorts of languages. I thought—if I worked in the industry and had trouble deciphering them, the task must feel overwhelming for customers trying to choose between a Cabeço das Nogueiras oil from Portugal and a Catalan Arbequina monocultivar. Where would they even begin? ![Lori Jean Levy](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/3929d351-4bec-43fb-8793-d366c430ff28/Lori+Jean+Levy+copy.jpg) Lori Jean Levy Years later, olive oil bottles can still feel intimidating. I talked to Lori Levy, my former Fairway colleague and CEO of[My Global Table](https://www.myglobaltable.com), and Nicholas Coleman, founder of[Grove and Vine](https://groveandvine.com)about how to decode olive oil labels. Here’s where to start. ![Dates on olive oil label](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/c4b9a8ef-ff72-4b3d-a1f7-f8a4290f53a1/Olive+oil+dates.jpeg) Olive oil dates ## Freshness is Key The fresher, the better. “The first thing I look for is the harvest date,” says Coleman. “Freshness is a key quality component.” Olive oil is at its best in its**first two years**. With time, olive oil slowly but surely loses its beautiful, complex flavors and health benefits. “Buy smaller, not bigger. It’s always best to have fresher oil than oxidized oil,” Levy advises. Olive oil harvests in the northern hemisphere (in countries like Greece, Spain, and Italy) take place in October and November. This means if you’re looking for the freshest bottle, you’ll want the harvest date listed on the label to be from the previous year. ![Pretty olive oil labels](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/851ec086-f7a9-4241-8ed5-96e0a3538c2c/Pretty+labels.jpeg) ## A Pretty Label is Just a Pretty Label Don’t judge a book by its cover. “Like wine, a fancy label can disguise,” says Levy. “So don’t be distracted from making decisions just on the front of the bottle.” Turn the bottle to the back, where the smaller print conveys crucial information. ![Olive oils from Italy](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/d3d1a51b-afbf-4bc4-8066-98def0689ff1/Labels+with+origin.jpeg) Olive oils from Italy ## Check the Region Coleman says to “Look for a**single estate or specific region**where the olives originate.” Lesser quality oils often blend olives from all sorts of regions and countries. Like wine, the most delicious EVOOs celebrate the terroir of a specific place. Also like wine, there are excellent oils to be discovered from all sorts of places around the world. When I spoke to Coleman, he was on his way home from an olive oil sourcing trip to Chile. Spain, Italy, Greece, and Portugal produce quality EVOO, as do Tunisia, Australia, California, and beyond. Levy urges customers to check if in oil was “packed, blended or otherwise processed somewhere other than where it was grown,” a piece of information that must appear on the bottle, legally (often in small print). That’s a sign of a lesser quality product. ## Extra Virgin is Just the Start **Extra Virgin**is the top tier of olive oil, and a great place to start. To be classified extra virgin, the oil must be extracted mechanically from olives, have an oleic acidity of less than 0.8%, and be free of defects, according to a tasting panel. Extra virgin olive oil is not chemically altered in any way. But EVOO doesn’t tell you much more than that about what’s inside the bottle. Even though it is the highest grade, the quality, aroma, flavor, color, and price can vary significantly from one bottle to another. ![Olive oil and tomatoes](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/92d6a8a6-2d44-4dbf-9bbf-32b98d74761e/bruschetta+by+Eva+from+Pixabay.jpg) ## Know How You’re Going to Use Your EVOO “There are Super Premium EVOOs, that really stand apart,” Levy explains. “They are more expensive to farm and produce and hence are costly.” Use these stunning oils for drizzling and finishing, so their flavors really shine through. Levy keeps at least two special EVOOs at hand, one delicate and one more robust in flavor to pair with different foods (olive oil should elevate, not overpower). “Then there are the workhorses of your kitchen, the EVOO that can do a multitude of things from cooking to dressings and marinades,” explains Levy. She uses older oils she is trying to finish up for this purpose, or a less expensive bottle from a producer she trusts. ![Olive oil bottle with cultivar on the label](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/fc7847ae-b00c-4ab2-a06d-4af0ba0f3dde/Olive+oil+bottle+with+cultivar.jpg) Olive oil bottle with cultivar on the label ## Get to know your cultivars Just as wine is made from different varieties of grapes, olive oil is made from different**olive culitivars**. The term**monocultivar**refers to an oil pressed from a single kind of olive—it’s not inherently better or worse, just a specific style. (More wine analogy—a Bordeaux is usually made from a blend of grapes, a Burgundy is exclusively Pinot Noir. Both are fabulous, and different.) “Much like choosing wine, once you know some of the characteristics of the cultivars you like, you are able to find what you are looking for or something similar,” says Levy. “And you may start to explore new cultivars from different countries.” Also like wine, regions tend to plant specific olives, with their own flavor profiles. For example, the vast majority of Picual olives are grown in Jaén, in Andalusia, Spain, and tend to have a light peppery taste, fruity flavor, and a little bitterness. Originating in Tuscany, Frantoio olives produce an aromatic, slightly spicy oil, with notes of almonds and fresh herbs. [ ![Pizza](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/6462edce4d7ed61838fab845/068b8b89-6b07-4226-a98a-48adf934f86a/Margherita+pizza+at+Pizzeria+Salvo+photo+credit+Aurora+Scotto+di+Minico.jpg) ](https://oliveoilprofessor.com/blog/choosing-the-best-extra-virgin-olive-oil-for-italian-pizza) Choosing the Best Extra Virgin Olive Oil for Pizza ## Tasting is the Best, Truest Way to Get to Know an olive Oil Ultimately, let your own taste buds be your guide. If you love the flavor of an olive oil, that’s what matters. “Be sure to taste an oil, on its own and independent of other foo...

# The Best Golden Sourdough Bread Recipe | Easy for Beginners
[Jump to Recipe](#recipe)[Print Recipe](https://simplytaralynn.com/wprm_print/perfect-sourdough-bread-loaf-golden-crispy-flavorful)
This**sourdough bread recipe**is perfect for beginners and bread experts. Low-maintenance and foolproof, it creates a beautifully**golden crust**with an airy, soft interior that’s perfectly chewy. It’s time to make the most gorgeous**sourdough bread**from home!
This post about my**sourdough bread**journey has been a long time coming. I’ve been working so hard to perfect my process, and although many have been begging for me to share my recipe, I didn’t want to post it when it wasn’t up to standards. I can confidently say that I have the**best-tasting sourdough bread recipe**for you to try. But this is just the beginning. I have more**sourdough bread recipes**coming your way, including**[posts on starters](https://simplytaralynn.com/2024/06/03/where-can-i-get-sourdough-starter-from-make-it-yourself/)**,**discard recipes**, sourdough bread flavors, scoring techniques, and more.
## ***The Best Golden Sourdough Bread Recipe | Easy Baking for Beginners***
We may have different preferences when it comes to**sourdough bread**. I love my bread to be airy, flavorful, golden, and crusty on the outside. I’m not a big fan of dark bread. I don’t cook mine at the highest temps that most sourdough bread recipes require. I rather mine cook longer at a lower temp and stay a bit more golden.
One of my favorite ways to eat sourdough bread is by toasting, adding a layer of butter, and my favorite, raspberry jam. We eat our bread by making turkey sandwiches, grilled cheese, and French toast, and I even love making croutons out of stale bread.
* * * * * * If you have an active starter already established, then this is the blog for you! No worries if you do not have an active starter; I wrote a**[tutorial on sourdough starter](https://simplytaralynn.com/2024/06/03/where-can-i-get-sourdough-starter-from-make-it-yourself/)**, and**[you can find that blog HERE](https://simplytaralynn.com/2024/06/03/where-can-i-get-sourdough-starter-from-make-it-yourself/)**
### ***Let’s start making and baking the best sourdough bread ever.***
It typically takes me 24 hours to make my bread from start to finish (from feeding my starter to baking) 24 hours sounds like a high-maintenance process, but I promise it’s not. There are a lot of hours where you just leave the bread alone to rise or leave the starter alone to activate. The process can be customized to fit any kind of schedule. The more you bake sourdough bread, the more you’ll find your groove when it comes to a timeline that works for you.
## ***Reasons why you will love an easy beginner’s sourdough bread recipe:***
1. **Simple ingredients:**This beginner sourdough bread recipe has a short list of simple ingredients, making it easy to get started with minimal fuss.
2. **Clear instructions:**This Beginner sourdough bread recipe has detailed instructions and step-by-step guidance, making it easy to follow along even if you’ve never made bread before.
3. **Healthy and natural:****Is sourdough the most healthy bread?**Sourdough bread is a healthier option than regular bread, as it contains more nutrients and is easier to digest. It’s also made with natural yeast, which is better for your gut microbiome.
4. **Delicious flavor:**Sourdough bread has a unique, tangy flavor that many people find irresistible. Plus, with a little practice, you can customize the flavor by adjusting the fermentation time, adding herbs or spices, or using different types of flour.
5. **Budget-friendly:**Making your own sourdough bread can be more cost-effective than buying it from a bakery or grocery store, especially if you’re buying high-quality artisan bread.
6. **Satisfaction of baking:**There’s something satisfying about making your own bread from scratch, and sourdough bread is no exception. Plus, it’s a great way to impress your friends and family with your baking skills!##### ***Sourdough Bread for Beginners***
## ***The Best Golden Sourdough Bread Recipe:***
Along with the**sourdough bread recipe**, I’ll be sharing tips and tricks to perfecting this sourdough bread and some fun ways to jazz it up.Sourdough bread is simple, and once you get the hang of it, you’ll naturally get more daring with the process. You may even put your own spin on the recipe and find a routine that works better for you. The more and more you play with sourdough, the more perfect your loaves turn out each time. It’s fun to look back and see how far I’ve come. I remember googling everything there was to know about sourdough starters, and after reading and watching all the videos, I was still so confused. Eventually, you catch on, and it makes you feel like you’re a bread scientist. I’m~~kind of~~obsessed with it at this point. I love trying new techniques, and I love watching others for inspiration. My for you page is just filled with sourdough videos and scoring art.
7. 8. #### [**read the blog:**](https://simplytaralynn.com/2025/01/09/where-can-i-get-sourdough-starter-from-make-it-yourself/)
## Understanding Sourdough Starter!
One of the most frequently asked questions I receive is, “How do I make a sourdough starter?” or “Where can I get a sourdough starter from?”
What is sourdough starter? How does it work?
I recommend beginning the sour starter process now, or purchasing an**[active sourdough starter on Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/shop/taralynnmcnitt/list/3CBBOL0VG3GYK?linkCode=spc&ref_=aip_sf_list_spv_ons_mixed_d)**. It took me about two weeks to make my starter, and if I’m being honest, I wish I had purchased a starter online to save myself the days of frustration. The good thing is that my starter is still thriving and making the most delicious loaves of bread. I’ve been meaning to name it, too. So, if you have any good name suggestions for my sourdough starter, please leave them in the comments. It always cracks me up listening to people talk to their starters and calling them by name.
## ***How did I start my sourdough bread journey?***
I have always admired bakers online making their bread. A few months ago, I was browsing the grocery store and looking to...

results.title: Official 2025 International Pizza Challenge Winners at Pizza Expo
results.text:
Pizza World Champions have been crowned at prestigious International Pizza Competition in Las Vegas

Pizza Champions have been crowned at the International Pizza Challenge during Pizza Expo in March. The world-renowned three-day competition saw 550 competitors from around the world competing to have their pizzas proclaimed the world’s best non-traditional pizza, traditional pizza, pan pizza, pizza Napoletana and cheese slice. Competitors in the international pizza competition went head-to-head in five divisions (Traditional, Non-Traditional, Neapolitan/STG, Pan and World’s Best Cheese Slice). Winners included first, second and third places in each division as well as regional Top 3 in Traditional, Non-Tradition and World’s Best Cheese Slice. International Pizza Challenge also award a Pizza Maker of Year Champion and Best of the Best Champion. For overall scoreboards from the competition, visit International Pizza Challenge Daily Results. Below are all winners by category and scores:

Pizza Maker of the Year 2025

Ryan Ososky presents his Pizza Maker of the Year Championship winning pizza to the judges at the International Pizza Challenge during Pizza Expo in Las Vegas. Photo courtesy of DTown Pizzeria.

Winners of the 5 pizza division (Traditional, Non-Traditional, Neapolitan/STG, Pan and World’s Best Cheese Slice) finals advance to the Pizza Maker of the Year Championship. Division Champions face off against each other in a mystery-ingredient (Trifoglio 100% Pure Extra Virgin Olive Oil) bake-off to be named World Champion. The winner of the Pizza Maker of the Year competition will claim the title of World Champion, a trophy and an additional $5,000 prize.

Pizza Maker of the Year World Champion 2025

Ryan Ososky (52.51) — DTown Pizzeria, Los Angeles, CA

Read a full feature on Ryan Ososky and his win.

Best of the Best 2025

Tony Cerimele wins Best of the Best at the 2025 International Pizza Challenge at Pizza Expo in Las Vegas

Tony Cerimele shows off his Best of the Best trophy and award-winning pizza at Pizza Expo 2025.

The current Pizza Maker of the Year and previous Pizza Maker of the Year winners are invited to compete in a Best of the Best battle. The winner of the Best of the Best competition will claim the title of Best of the Best Champion, a trophy and $2,500 prize.

Best of the Best Champion 2025

Anthony Cerimele (54.90) — New Columbus Pizza Co., Pittston, PA

Read a full feature on Anthony Cerimele and his win.

Traditional Pizza Division Winners 2025

Wilhelm Rodriguez of Papas Pizza, Cabo Rojo, Puerto Rico, wins the Traditional Division at the International Pizza Challenge during Pizza Expo in Las Vegas.

Wilhelm Rodriguez presents his award-winning pie at the 2025 International Pizza Challenge.

The Traditional Division saw 100 competitors in a category with tight restrictions. The pizzas must have a red sauce, and competitors may only use two of the following toppings: Pepperoni, Sausage, Bacon, Ham, Mushrooms, Peppers, Tomatoes, Onions, and Olives. Once the pizza enters the oven, only a drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil (infused or not) is acceptable. No other toppings, fresh basil, cheeses, spices &/or finishers can be added once the pizza enters the oven. The winner of the Traditional Division receives a trophy and $7,500. Second and third place receive $2,000 and $1,000 respectively. Regional winners from the Traditional Division receive a recognition plaque and $500.

Traditional Division Finals Winners

1st. Wilhelm Rodriguez (42.68) — Papas Pizza, Cabo Rojo, PR

2nd. Chris Battiste (42.25) — Miaava East Coast Pizza, Pahrump, NV

3rd. Fiodar Huminski (39.78) – Pizzeria No 900, Montreal, QC, Canada

Read a full feature on Wilhelm Rodriguez and his win.

Regional Pizza Winners in the Traditional Division 2025

In addition to awarding 1st, 2nd and 3rd in best traditional pizza in the Finals, pizza makers from the southwest, southeast, midwest, northeast and northwest United States, as well as an International region, also receive a top three pizza ranking. They are:

Traditional Preliminaries – Southwest Region Winners
1st. Alex Yeatts (42.69) — Unknown Pizza, Dallas, TX

2nd. Chris Battiste (42.61) — Miaava East Coast Pizza, Pahrump, NV

3rd. Nathan Santarini (42.52) — Sleight of Hand Pizza, Santa Cruz, CA

Traditional Preliminaries – Southeast Region Winners
1st. Jamie Culliton (41.03) — The Nona Slice House, Safety Harbor, FL

2nd. Gerald Addison (40.94) — Grazie Nonna, Washington, DC

3rd. Camryn Suggs (40.01) — Valentina’s Pizzeria & Wine Bar, Madison, AL

Traditional Preliminaries – Midwest Region Winners
1st. Kyle Rosch (40.40) — Brenz Pizza Company, Columbus, OH

2nd. Giovanni Labbate (39.31) — Tievoli Pizza Bar, Palatine, IL

3rd. Daulton Cornell (39.05) — Six Hundred Downtown, Bellefontaine, OH

Traditional Preliminaries – Northwest Region Winners
1st. Tissoyo Davis (40.79) — Wind River Pizza, Lander, WY

2nd. Mikey Scoville (40.44) – Righteous Slice, Rexburg, ID

3rd. Ruben Armas (40.00) — South Town Pie, Seattle, WA

Traditional Preliminaries – Northeast Region Winners
1st. Patrick Elston (39.87) — Gus Francos Pizza, Lower Burrell, PA

2nd. Apaar Verma (39.21) — Pizza Love, LLC, dba The Onion Tree Pizza, New York, NY

3rd. Chris Weisman (38.82) — Pizzeria Baci, Montrose, NY

Traditional Preliminaries – International Winners
1st. Wilhelm Rodriguez (43.73) — Papas Pizza, Cabo Rojo, PR

2nd. Fiodar Huminski (41.78) — Pizzeria No 900, Montreal, QC

3rd. Paulo Guerra (41.52) — Gatto Wood Oven Pizza, Toronto, ON

Non-Traditional Pizza Division Winners 2025

Leo Dicesaris of Cerrone’s Brick Oven Pizzeria in Columbus, Georgi, wins Non-Traditional Pizza Division at...

results.title: GAME OF SKILL
results.text:
“YOUR LOCAL CLUB PERFECT PLATE AWARDS” 2025 PROMOTION
TERMS AND CONDITIONS
1. The “Your Local Club Perfect Plate Awards” Promotion consists of four (4) parts:
• Part 1: Perfect Plate Clubs Game of Skill Competition;
• Part 2: Perfect Plate Patron Game of Skill Competition – Foodie Escape;
• Part 3: Perfect Plate Patron Random Draw Competition– Dining Vouchers; and
• Part 4: Perfect Plate Clubs Random Draw Competition – Lucky Door Prize
Part 1, Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4 are collectively referred to as the “Promotion” and comprise 
the “Terms and Conditions”.
2. Information on how to enter, vote and participate in the Promotion and the prizes to be won 
through the Promotion are contained in these Terms and Conditions. Participation in the 
Promotion is deemed acceptance of these Terms and Conditions and the Promoter’s Personal 
Information Collection Notice, which can be viewed at
https://www.clubsnsw.com.au/sites/default/files/2025-01/PP25_PICollection.pdf.
3. The promoter is The Registered Clubs Association of New South Wales (ABN 61 724 302 100)
of Level 8, 51 Druitt Street, Sydney, NSW 2000 (“Promoter”). The Promoter is conducting the 
Promotion.
4. The organisations benefiting from this Promotion are each of the Eligible Clubs which enter the 
Perfect Plate Clubs Game of Skill Competition in accordance with these Terms and Conditions. 
5. The following persons are prohibited from participating in the Promotion:
• employees of the Promoter and their immediate families;
• any persons conducting the Promotion, including any person who determines who is to 
win a prize in the Promotion; and
• a person who is involved in the management of any organisation benefiting from this 
Promotion, including each of the Eligible clubs which enter the Perfect Plate Clubs Game 
of Skill Competition in accordance with these Terms and Conditions. 
“Immediate family” means any of the following: spouse, ex-spouse, de-facto spouse, child or 
step-child (whether natural or by adoption), parent, step-parent, grandparent, step-grandparent, 
uncle, aunt, niece, nephew, brother, sister, step-brother, step-sister or first cousin.
6. The Promotion commences at 9:00AM AEDT on 10 March 2025 and ends at 11:59PM AEST
on 15 June 2025 (“Promotional Period”).
PART 1: PERFECT PLATE CLUBS GAME OF SKILL COMPETITION
General Information
7. The Perfect Plate Clubs Game of Skill Competition commences at 9:00AM AEDT on 10 March 
2025 and ends at 11:59PM AEST on 18 April 2025.
8. Entry into the “Perfect Plate Clubs Game of Skill Competition” is only open to clubs in New 
South Wales that hold a current membership with the Promoter (“Eligible Club”).
9. To be eligible to enter under a competition category listed in clause 17:
(a) for the Regional Categories and Club Size Categories, an Eligible Club must create a
savoury dish, which must not be a Pizza or dessert dish, and list it on their menu for the 
Voting Period (Main Plate Competition Dish);
“Your Local Club Perfect Plate Awards” Promotion - Terms and Conditions
Page 2 of 14
(b) for the Best Pizza Category, an Eligible Club must create a pizza dish and list it on their 
menu for the Voting Period (Pizza Competition Dish); and
(c) for the Best Dessert Category, an Eligible Club must create a dessert dish and list it on 
their menu for the Voting Period (Dessert Competition Dish).
10. References to "Competition Dish” in these Terms and Conditions refers to a dish which is 
eligible to be submitted to enter a particular competition category, in accordance with clause 9.
11. The Competition Dish must be displayed and sold as a full-priced item and not at a discounted 
price, except where the Competition Dish is discounted as a result of a valid club member 
discount being applied. A Competition Dish which is designed to be shared among more than 
one (1) person can only receive one (1) vote per purchase. 
12. To enter a Competition Dish, Eligible Clubs must complete the following steps:
• Visit www.perfectplate.com.au (“Promotion Entry Page”);
• Follow the prompts to the Promotion Entry Page;
• Input the requested details in the entry form on the Promotion Entry Page, being the first 
and last name, mobile number, email address and job title of the Eligible Club’s primary 
contact, and the name of the Eligible Club; 
• Click the “Next’ button to agree to these Terms and Conditions and the Promoter’s 
Personal Information Collection Notice, and to consent to the conduct of the Promotion; 
• Input the name of the eatery within the Eligible Club serving the Competition Dish, the 
name of the Competition Dish, a description of the Competition Dish, the name of the 
chef who created the Competition Dish, the sale price of the Competition Dish and an 
image of the Competition Dish; and
• Submit the fully completed entry form between 9:00AM AEDT on 10 March 2025 and
11:59PM AEST on18 April 2025.
13. By submitting an entry in the Clubs Game of Skill Competition, the Eligible Club is providing its 
written consent to the conduct of the Promotion.
14. Eligible Clubs may submit more than one (1) entry, subject to the following: (a) only one (1) 
Main Plate Competition Dish, one (1) Pizza Competition Dish, one (1) Dessert Competition Dish
can be entered per restaurant/eatery within an Eligible Club; (b) each Competition Dish entered 
by an Eligible Club must be substantially unique to any other Competition Dish entered by the
same Eligible Club; and (c) each Competition Dish must be submitted separately and in 
accordance with entry requirements set out in these Terms and Conditions.
15. At the conclusion of the Promotional Period, the Promoter will tally the number of votes received 
from Eligible Patrons during the Voting Period for each eligible Competition Dish.
16. If physical voting forms are completed by Eligible Patrons in accordance with clause 48, Eligible 
Clubs are responsible for uploading a copy of the physical voting forms completed by Eligible 
Patrons in accordance with clause 48 and the corresponding purchase receipt to the Perfect 
Plate website www.perfectplate.com.au using the club register portal by 5:00PM AEST on 18
June 2025 in order for the Promoter to count the vote recorded on the physical voting form. 
The Promoter reserves the right to require the Eligible Club to send the Promoter the physical 
voting forms and the corresponding purchase receipt for verification purposes, and if such 
request is made by the Promoter, the Eligible Club must provide the physical voting forms and 
corresponding purchase receipt to the Promoter before 5:00PM AEST on 28 June 2025. If the 
physical voting forms and corresponding purchase receipt are not received by this date, the 
Promoter may deem the entry to be invalid. Any physical voting forms uploaded by an Eligible 
Club which does not contain a corresponding purchase receipt will be deemed invalid. Physical 
voting forms provided to Eligible Patrons must not be altered or modified by the Eligible Club. 
Any physical voting forms uploaded by an Eligible Club which have been altered or modified by 
an Eligible Club will be deemed invalid. Staff of Eligible Clubs are prohibited from completing a 
voting form (including the score) on behalf of the entrant.
“Your Local Club Perfect Plate Awards” Promotion - Terms and Conditions
Page 3 of 14
Competition Categories 
17. Entries will be divided into: 
(a) Regional Categories;
(b) Club Size Categories;
(c) Best Pizza Category; and 
(d) Best Dessert Category.
The Regional Categories and Club Size Categories listed below are based on the location and 
size of the Eligible Club. The Club Size categories are also based on the size of each of the 
Eligible Clubs’ current membership numbers in the Promoter’s database as at the 
commencement date of the Promotional Period. 
The 13 regional categories (“Regional Categories”) are listed below:
• Newcastle & Hunter Valley
• Far North Coast
• New England Tablelands & North West
• Central West
• Riverina &...
